comment.body: @xvzcf When implementing a direct upstream-copy of Dilithium, I only found this now :-( Do I read this right in that it removes OSX support for Dilithium? Why is this so? Wouldn't it make sense to mark this up as a ToDo? Wouldn't it be worth while to correct this in PQClean if you think it's wrong there? In any case, this is one more reason to work on importing straight from upstream pqcrystals as OSX is supported and working there...

@@ -67,6 +67,13 @@ def load_instructions():
         family['family'] = family['name']
         for scheme in family['schemes']:
             scheme['metadata'] = yaml.safe_load(file_get_contents(os.path.join(os.environ['PQCLEAN_DIR'], 'crypto_sign', scheme['pqclean_scheme'], 'META.yml')))
+            # This is a temporary hack to work around the fact that
comment.body:
Ah I see [below](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs/pull/726/files/eab0e5492d254c7b98be464cf2afc5776b1b0b2f#diff-92fe1cb95aca55f702b1f28d5220c5caR74) disables OSX support. The reason for that is probably that there is something going on which makes life slightly complicated.

There are unaligned operations being done using `_mm256_loadu_si256` or one of its brethren. These of course need vector types — but `__m256i*` is 8-byte aligned in newer versions of GCC and Clang! This leads to compiler warnings / errors when casting array pointers to `__m256i*`. The unaligned variant, `_m256i_u` is only available in fairly new versions of the compilers, though...

comment.body:
> With regards to the upstream versions of Dilithium and Kyber in PQClean: Dilithium in PQClean already has OSX support, for Kyber we still need to apply the same set of patches. We would definitely welcome help there, as we obviously only have so much time and our contributions are mostly driven by our direct research needs — we need to write papers after all. 

@thomwiggers Can you share some information what this support would entail? How much effort is a `pqcrystals` to `PQClean` import usually? (Sorry for the possibly trivial question, I've never looked at PQClean internals so far). Do you see any chance (for anyone) to get an automated import (like from `PQClean` to `liboqs`) realised?

comment.body:
Probably not worth the time, the changes are so infrequent that it's probably lower effort to just port them manually each time.

What would save time is doing the work to bring PQCRYSTALS upstream in line with PQClean's test suite, and then merging those changes back. Once that is done, I imagine you could more directly import the changes. Unfortunately, such back-PRs are often quite messy to review.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -67,6 +67,13 @@ def load_instructions():
         family['family'] = family['name']
         for scheme in family['schemes']:
             scheme['metadata'] = yaml.safe_load(file_get_contents(os.path.join(os.environ['PQCLEAN_DIR'], 'crypto_sign', scheme['pqclean_scheme'], 'META.yml')))
+            # This is a temporary hack to work around the fact that
comment.body:
Updating Kyber to support OSX is mainly making sure the symbols work in the assembly files: the C ABI on Linux just translates `void functionname()` to the label `functionname`, on OSX (and Windows) it's prefixed with an underscore: `_functionname`. 

For the most part, you just need labels in the assembly to also exist in the underscore-prefixed versions. If you reference variables/constants defined in C files, it gets a bit more messy and you will need compiler macros (see https://github.com/PQClean/PQClean/blob/master/crypto_sign/dilithium3/avx2/cdecl.inc)
